title: $1,973 LEDs and the Green New Deal
summary: How many union workers does it take to screw in a light bulb?.

title: Another Subsidy Letdown
summary: Boston lured GE with millions. The company is now paying it back.. This has been an ugly few weeks for corporate "incentives." Amazon left New York at the altar, turning down a dowry of $3 billion in subsidies. Foxconn's promised new factory in Wisconsin, enticed with $4 billion in incentives, has fallen into doubt. Democratic Governor Tony Eversis even being urged to reconsider its environmental impact.

title: Presidents and Guardrails
summary: Obama's abuses are no justification for Trump's emergency order..

title: New Jersey Attorney General Sends Subpoena to Trump Inaugural Committee
summary: Subpoena is second this month sent to committee, which is under criminal investigation by Manhattan federal prosecutors. President Trump's inaugural committee has received a civil subpoena from the New Jersey attorney general, whose Consumer Protection Division is conducting an investigation into the fund, a committee spokeswoman said Friday.

title: Euro Falls Amid Talk of New ECB Bank Loans
summary: Comments by European Central Bank board member seen as a sign of economic weakness. The euro fell against the U.S. dollar and other developed-market currencies after investors interpreted a European Central Bank official's discussion of a lending program for banks as a sign of the region's economic weakness.

title: Passaic River Cleanup Lawsuit Against YPF Headed to Trial
summary: Bankruptcy court refuses to dismiss creditor suit over environmental costs. Argentina's YPF S.A. on Friday lost a bid for a pretrial victory in a multibillion-dollar fight over the cost of cleaning up the contaminated Passaic River.

title: The Making of a DNA Detective
summary: CeCe Moore, an amateur genealogist turned professional, helps police crack decades-old cases.. Christy Mirack was murdered in 1992, but the case wasn't solved until last year. The 25-year-old sixth-grade teacher was found dead in her home near Lancaster, Pa., naked from the waist down. She had been beaten, strangled and sexually assaulted. Police collected a semen sample, ran it through a DNA database, and found no matches. The crime went into a cold-case file.

title: Gas Shortages Give New York an Early Taste of the Green New Deal
summary: The state is dependent on imports even though it sits atop the abundant Marcellus Shale.. The combination of hydraulic fracturing and horizontal drilling-sometimes known as the "shale revolution"-has enabled Texas, Pennsylvania and other states to produce record quantities of natural gas, some of which is being frozen, loaded onto giant ships, and transported to customers in places like Chile, China and India. Thanks to the environmental policies of Gov. Andrew Cuomo, New York has missed out on this windfall.

title: Notable & Quotable: Ocasio-Cortez's Aide
summary: 'He was in fact a registered lobbyist for the Marijuana Policy Project.'. Cameron Cawthornereporting for the Washington Free Beacon, Feb. 14:

title: America Is Torn Between Trump's Fibs and Progressives' Fantasies
summary: The president is a master of little lies, but the left rejects the big truths that sustain politics and culture.. As a teenager in the 1930s, my mother was an idealistic, card-carrying member of the Communist Party. Then came Stalin's Moscow show trials. The scales fell from her eyes. She quit the party. Her Philadelphia cell declared her "an enemy of the people." She was proud of that, but she went on listening to Paul Robeson records. As the years passed she gave up Trotsky for Adlai Stevenson.

title: Citigroup Gives CEO 4% Pay Raise to $24 Million
summary: For 2018, the bank reported net income of $18 billion on revenues of $72.9 billion. Citigroup Inc. Chief Executive Michael Corbat received a compensation package valued at $24 million in 2018, a 4% raise from the $23 million he earned in the prior year, according to a securities filing Friday.

title: Judge Rules Roger Stone Can't Make Media Appearances Outside Courthouse
summary: Informal adviser to President Trump, facing criminal charges in Washington, can still make public statements elsewhere. WASHINGTON-Roger Stone won't be able talk to the media outside the courthouse where he is expected to face trial, a federal judge ruled Friday, saying that she wanted to ensure she could find a jury not "tainted" by the publicity surrounding the criminal case against the informal adviser to President Trump.

title: PepsiCo CEO Says No Plans to Break Up
summary: Ramon Laguarta sees 'no need to shed or acquire businesses' and sets new restructuring plan. PepsiCo Inc.'s new Chief Executive Ramon Laguarta said he has no plans to break up the snacks and drinks giant, nor divest the company's bottling operations, after completing a four-month review of the global business.

title: Judge Rules Westmoreland Coal Can Cut Retiree Benefits, Union Contracts
summary: Ruling comes after Westmoreland's advisers testified dramatic cuts to its labor liabilities were needed to avert a worse outcome in liquidation. Westmoreland Coal Co. has received permission to end retiree benefits and scrap its union contracts with workers at two of its mines after the company said it needed to make dramatic cuts to its labor costs to survive bankruptcy.

title: Investor Steve Jurvetson Works to Move On With New Fund
summary: As he launches a new fund, the venture capitalist discusses his departure from Draper Fisher Jurvetson. Steve Jurvetson said his world came crashing down in the fall of 2017, after allegations surfaced of misconduct at the venture-capital firm he co-founded. Now the prominent investor is attempting a comeback, raising a new fund and defending himself while admitting to mistakes.

title: Appeals Court Says Puerto Rico Board Was Illegally Appointed
summary: Ruling will allow bankruptcy proceedings to continue. The board overseeing Puerto Rico's public finances was illegally appointed, a U.S. appeals court said in a Friday ruling that casts uncertainty over the U.S. territory's high-stakes financial restructuring.

title: Toys 'R' Dust: Mattel's Bizarre Warning
summary: The toymaker's lowered forecast has severely damaged its credibility. Mattel , maker of Barbie and Hot Wheels toys, was riding high when it reported fourth-quarter earnings last week. While the company had been lagging Hasbro , its holiday sales performance seemed to leave its rival in the dust. Investors sent Mattel's stock up 26% the session after it released earnings while Hasbro's sank. But at an analyst meeting on Friday, Mattel downgraded its forecast for 2019. All that smugness deflated like a balloon, and so did the stock. It suffered its worst percentage drop of this century, losing 18% of its value Friday.

title: Ethics Office Notes Show 'Evolving Stories' on Trump's Reimbursement of Cohen, House Oversight Committee Says
summary: Panel sends letters to Trump Organization and White House inquiring about reimbursement for hush-money payments Trump's lawyer arranged. WASHINGTON-The House Oversight Committee in a letter to the White House on Friday said it had received new documents from the Office of Government Ethics that showed President Trump's lawyers gave the agency "evolving stories" about whether the president had reimbursed his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, for hush-money payments made during the 2016 campaign.

title: Kaepernick Resolves Collusion Grievance With NFL
summary: Former 49ers stars had alleged the league and its teams conspired to keep them unsigned because of roles in protest movement.

title: Contradictory Data Confound Economists
summary: U.S. economy appears to be shifting to a slower gear, which could bring more choppy reports. WASHINGTON-Economic data are usually noisy, but this week included an onslaught of negative and often contradictory signals that made even seasoned economists scratch their heads.

title: Commander Says U.S. Has Flexibility to Keep Some Troops in Syria
summary: Trump administration is debating a continued presence to counter Iran. MUSCAT, OMAN-The top U.S. commander in the Middle East said he is moving forward with plans to pull American forces out of Syria, but said the military has the flexibility to leave some troops there if President Trump decides to maintain an American presence in Syria as a counter to Iran.

title: Transcript: WSJ Interview With San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly
summary: Official discusses her outlook for interest rates and the economy and the winding down of the Fed's bond portfolio. Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly was interviewed by The Wall Street Journal's Michael S. Derby on Thursday, Feb. 14, 2019. She discussed her outlook for interest rates and the economy, the winding down of the Fed's bond portfolio, and reasons why a tight labor market hasn't fueled stronger wage growth and higher inflation. Here is a transcript of the interview, lightly edited for clarity.

title: Industrial Stocks Are Leading the Market for the First Time in Years
summary: S&P 500's industrials sector has led recent rebound, but trade talks loom as a risk if deal isn't reached. Industrial shares are on track to drive the stock market's gains on a quarterly basis for the first time in more than five years, fueling anxiety about a rapid unwind should trade negotiations with China stall.

title: Private-Equity Firm Great Hill Partners in Talks to Buy Gizmodo Media Group
summary: Univision put its English-language digital unit, which includes the Onion and Gizmodo, up for sale in July. Great Hill Partners is in exclusive talks with Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications Inc. to buy Gizmodo Media Group, according to people familiar with the matter, a deal that would add a marquee digital brand to the private-equity firm's portfolio.

title: Nasdaq Exits Bear Market as Stocks Rally
summary: The tech-heavy index closed more than 20% above its Christmas Eve low, entering a new bull-market run. The new year rally in technology stocks lifted the Nasdaq Composite to its eighth consecutive weekly rise and propelled the index out of the bear market it entered in late 2018.

title: Secrets of Wealthy Women: How to Become an Angel Investor
summary: Gotham Gal blogger talks about mentoring startup founders-and realizing it's a big gamble. Joanne Wilson, angel investor and author of the Gotham Gal blog, says investing in startups is both highly risky and rewarding.

title: Photos of the Week: Feb. 9-15, 2019
summary: Iran marks its 40th anniversary, a Belgian castle is on the market, an uphill battle for fashion, and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.S. Treasury Yields Tick Higher Amid Trade Hopes
summary: Yields head higher along with stocks amid signs of progress in the U.S.-China trade negotiations. U.S. government bond prices edged lower Friday but hovered in a narrow range as traders favored riskier assets amid signs of progress in U.S.-China trade talks.

title: Oil Climbs as OPEC Supply Drops
summary: Global benchmark gains 6.7% for week. •Oil prices ended at a near-three-month high on Friday, closing out a week of robust gains driven by signs of shrinking global supply.

title: Big Three Stock Exchanges Sue SEC Over Trading-Fee Plan
summary: NYSE, Nasdaq, Cboe seek to scrap initiative that would limit fees they can charge for trading. In an unprecedented legal confrontation, the three biggest U.S. stock-exchange groups are taking on their own regulator to block an initiative that seeks to limit the fees they can charge for trading.

title: Amazon's Pivot Raises Scrutiny of Incentive Deals
summary: New York bills call for compacts with other states promising to not provide any company-specific subsidies. The collapse of Amazon.com Inc.'s plan to build a second headquarters in New York City has the potential to damp some states' willingness to offer tax breaks.

title: Apollo to Buy Majority Stake in Cox TV Stations
summary: The deal will also include a majority stake in Ohio newspapers and radio stations. Apollo Global Management LLC has taken the first step to becoming one of the nation's biggest owners of local television stations.

title: Mexico Relocates Hundreds of Migrants From Border City
summary: Relocation seeks to disband group of some 1,400 Central American asylum seekers. MEXICO CITY-Hundreds of Central American migrants encamped in Mexico's border city of Piedras Negras, across from Eagle Pass, Texas, are being relocated to other cities after a group of migrants rioted earlier this week and attempted to leave an abandoned factory where they were being held.

title: How Trump's Border Wall Turned Into a National Emergency
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-President Trump's declaration of a national emergency to build a wall on the U.S. southern border comes after two years of political neglect of his signature campaign promise, lost amid competing priorities and divisions within his administration, according to current and former White House officials, lawmakers and congressional staffers.

title: Amazon to New York: It's Not Me, It's You
summary: Community's willingness to embrace a firm is often what clinches the deal for big companies seeking to expand in new locations. The list that Amazon.com Inc. sent to cities vying for its second headquarters a year and a half ago included the obvious stuff. Needs included a robust pipeline for tech workers, tax breaks, good real estate.

title: Russia Detains American Founder of Private-Equity Firm, Straining U.S. Ties Further
summary: Russia is also holding Paul Whelan, a U.S. citizen detained and charged with espionage. MOSCOW-A Moscow district court Friday agreed to extend to Saturday the preliminary detention of the American founder of a private equity group held on suspicion of fraud, an incident that could rattle potential foreign investors and add to already strained ties between the U.S. and Russia.

title: An American Icon That Almost Wasn't
summary: Daniel Chester French's famed statue in the Lincoln Memorial exists thanks to artistic perseverance, political determination, and a little luck..

title: Ilhan Omar's History of America
summary: The United States as Cold War villain.. Not that it will make Israelis feel any better, but Rep. Ilhan Omar (D., Minn.) doesn't seem to like America all that much, either.

title: Former Massachusetts Gov. Weld Launches Long-Shot Primary Challenge to Trump
summary: Weld is first Republican to challenge Trump; says president is 'too unstable' to lead. Former Massachusetts Gov. William Weld said Friday he is forming a presidential exploratory committee to challenge President Trump in the Republican primaries, offering a blistering critique of the president in a long-shot bid to deny him a second term.

title: Two Former Cognizant Executives Charged in Bribery Probe
summary: Outsourcing-operations company agrees to pay $25 million settlement, and it will not be prosecuted. Two former executives of outsourcing-operations company Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp. were charged by U.S. authorities with foreign bribery for allegedly approving illicit payments to help build a corporate campus in India.

title: Supreme Court Agrees to Decide Census Citizenship Question
summary: The 10-year questionnaire to U.S. residents is used to allocate government funding and reshape the number of congressional seats. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court announced Friday that it would move quickly to decide whether the Trump administration can ask U.S. residents on the 2020 census whether they are citizens, a case infused with time pressures and immigration politics.

title: GE to Scale Back Boston HQ, Return $87 Million of Incentives
summary: Company will sell properties and keep executives, smaller staff at Boston waterfront site. BOSTON- General Electric Co. is scaling back its planned Boston headquarters, including selling the property and dropping plans to add hundreds of jobs, because the shrinking conglomerate no longer needs the facilities.

title: Canada's Trudeau Looks to Contain Fallout from Justice Uproar
summary: Prime minister says he told former justice minister decision to prosecute SNC-Lavalin was up to her. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attempted to contain the fallout Friday of a political firestorm over allegations of judicial interference, saying he told his former justice minister the decision of whether to prosecute a global engineering company on bribery-and-fraud charges was hers.

title: Fed's Daly Sees Good Chance of No Rate Rises This Year
summary: San Francisco Fed chief says 'too early to judge' policy path but increases might not be needed in 2019 if U.S. economy performs as expected. SAN FRANCISCO-Mary Daly, the new head of the San Francisco Federal Reserve, said there is a good chance the U.S. central bank won't raise interest rates in 2019.

title: The Economy Is Probably Fine, but ...
summary: Unexpectedly soft industrial production figures add to signs economy has hit at least a temporary bout of weakness.. The economy's soft patch keeps looking softer.

title: Deere Says Trade Tensions Holding Down Sales
summary: Farmers are waiting for more clarity on trade deals before buying equipment. Deere & Co. said farmers are delaying purchases of machinery as they wait for a resolution of trade standoffs between the U.S. and major foreign buyers of farm commodities such as China.

title: Virginia's Black Caucus Gains Strength Amid Political Turmoil
summary: African-American state lawmakers have taken lead in getting through a crisis inextricably tied to race. When Virginia Democrats held a conference call Sunday on the state's latest leadership crisis, several African-American lawmakers spoke first and cited legal and political objections to an effort to impeach Lt. Gov. Justin Fairfax over sexual-assault allegations.

title: When Investing on Auto-Pilot Isn't Enough
summary: Investors must practice eternal vigilance, especially if they're tying their money up in illiquid assets. Nowadays, more and more investors are taking a buy-and-hold, "set-it-and-forget-it" attitude. Recent events at Highland Global Allocation Fund are a reminder that eternal vigilance is the price of investing.

title: Vatican Envoy to France Is Investigated for Sexual Assault Charge
summary: Paris prosecutors open inquiry after receiving complaint about Archbishop Luigi Ventura. PARIS-French authorities placed the Vatican's envoy to France under investigation for allegedly sexually assaulting a local Paris official last month, the latest in a string of embarrassing episodes involving Holy See diplomats.

title: Democrats Take Aim at the Reagan Tax Revolution
summary: Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez want big tax hikes on the rich to fight inequality, but such measures have usually succeeded only at moments of national crisis. For decades, the debate in the U.S. over taxing the rich has been a familiar game of tug of war. Republican presidents Ronald Reagan, George W. Bush and Donald Trump pushed top tax rates down. Democratic presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama pushed them back up.

title: Newell Warns That Sales Declines Will Continue
summary: Shares sink on forecast from maker of Rubbermaid, Sharpies and Elmer's glue. Newell Brands Inc. forecast another year of sales declines at the consumer-goods conglomerate even though one of its business segments returned to growth in its latest quarter.

title: Mexico Unveils Plan to Support State Oil Company Pemex
summary: New government hopes $5.2 billion rescue package would help stem the state oil company's bleeding. MEXICO CITY-Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador unveiled a $5.2 billion rescue package for Petróleos Mexicanos, which the new government hopes will help stem the state oil company's bleeding and reverse falling output.

title: Uber Sales Growth Slows Further as IPO Nears
summary: The ride-hailing company is aiming for a float that could value it at as much as $120 billion.. As it steers toward a planned initial public offering later this year, Uber Technologies Inc. is hitting a bumpy patch on sales.

title: Failing at Love? Maybe It's Time for Classes
summary: In South Korea, college-level dating classes are proliferating. Yes, there will be a quiz.. SEOUL-Lee In-ji, a 21-year-old college student, found herself flirting with a young man recently.

title: South Dakota Sen. Rounds Calls for Evaluation of Indian Health Service
summary: Rounds, a Republican, introduces bill to assess health agency's leadership and how it allocates money to its hospitals. Sen. Mike Rounds, a South Dakota Republican, introduced legislation Thursday calling for a broad assessment of the U.S. Indian Health Service, following an investigation of the agency by The Wall Street Journal and the PBS series Frontline.

title: Wells Fargo Chief Is Expected to Appear Solo Before House Panel
summary: Timothy Sloan to testify alone before the House Financial Services Committee in March, and then again in April in a joint appearance with other big-bank chiefs. WASHINGTON- Wells Fargo & Co. Chief Executive Timothy Sloan is expected to appear solo before the House Financial Services Committee on March 12, people familiar with the matter said, as the committee reviews the bank's consumer-abuse scandals.

title: The Stadium Reverse Curse
summary: A big bank merger shows that naming deals aren't always bad for companies, but they still cause confusion. Most of us have heard of the Stadium Curse-the phenomenon in which companies soon go bankrupt, or worse, after affixing their names to a sports venue. There was Enron Field, Adelphia Coliseum, the Transworld Dome and many others.

title: Illinois Governor to Sign Bill Raising Minimum Wage to $15 an Hour by 2025
summary: Business groups oppose labor-backed measure raising minimum from $8.25. Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker is expected to sign a bill approved by the Democrat-controlled state legislature to raise the state minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2025, a move that is sharply opposed by businesses throughout the state.

title: EU's Trade Surplus With U.S., a Bone of Contention for Trump, Hits Record
summary: Trade talks could suffer a fresh blow if the Trump administration moves toward hefty tariffs on European car imports. The European Union reported a record trade surplus with the U.S. last year, a development that could weigh on slow-moving U.S.-EU trade talks and comes as the Trump administration prepares to deliberate hefty tariffs on European car imports.

title: The Good Death: On Leaving This World in a Satisfying Way
summary: But I worry that the desire to have a "good" death adds to a patient's burden of health-associated guilt in this complex and unpredictable world.. I agree wholeheartedly with much of the advice in "Preparing For a Good End Of Life" (Review, Feb. 9), and while it would be great if we could all go out peacefully listening to Willie Nelson under the stars, my experience suggests the following two caveats.

title: Management Guru Jim Collins Is Probing New Problems
summary: After decades devoted to the mechanics of corporate success, Mr. Collins is turning his attention to K-12 education and the secrets of self-renewal. Jim Collins was having a +2 day.

title: His Predecessors Set a Low Bar for President Trump's Crisis Handling
summary: Peggy Noonan glosses over the crises of other presidents and homes in on how President Trump might poorly respond in such situations.. In "Can Trump Handle a Foreign Crisis?" (Declarations, Feb. 9), Peggy Noonan glosses over the crises of other presidents and homes in on how President Trump might poorly respond in such situations. Ms. Noonan suggests that Mr. Trump's rift with the intelligence community is problematic, noting "intelligence is front and center during a crisis."

title: Scott Walker Was Productively Conservative to the End
summary: Wisconsin's former Gov. Walker's achievements include steady year-by-year reduction of the burden of government, record low unemployment, high educational results and a near-best rating in funding of public pensions.. Your editorial about "Arkansas Tax Cutters" (Feb. 9) reads positively until the second-to-the-last sentence, with your swipe at former Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker. In fact, Gov. Walker continued to serve Wisconsin with admirable conservative competence in his second term. Check the recent Wisconsin Policy Forum report which says that 2018 was the "seventh consecutive annual decrease" in Wisconsin's tax burden, as measured by state and local taxes as a share of personal income. This burden declined to its lowest level in 50 years. How many other states have had that record, with particular reference to our neighbors in Illinois?

title: India's Modi Warns Pakistan of Reprisal for Kashmir Attack
summary: Suicide bombing claimed by Pakistan-based militants kills at least 40 Indian paramilitary policemen, sparking outrage. NEW DELHI-Indian authorities said they would punish Pakistan for an attack that killed at least 40 Indian security personnel, putting India's long-festering friction with its neighbor and the people of Kashmir at the center of political debate just months ahead of national elections.

title: Thoughts on Sears Long Decline and Edward Lampert's Bankruptcy Bid
summary: Buy a solid, ongoing business with valuable assets. Load it with debt that pays you back. Invest nothing in the business. Strip out most of the assets that have any value.. Wow, what a deal ("Lampert's Sears Bid Gets a Nod," Business News, Feb. 8). Buy a solid, ongoing business with valuable assets. Load it with debt that pays you back. Invest nothing in the business. Strip out most of the assets that have any value. Declare bankruptcy. Unload pensions to the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corp. Buy what's left for pennies on the dollar. Brilliant! And people wonder why hedge-fund guys are hated. Guess this is what I missed by not going to business school.

title: Coke and Pepsi Leave Different Aftertastes
summary: Results highlight similar strains facing U.S. consumer-goods companies. On the surface, Coca-Cola and PepsiCo reported similar sets of earnings back-to-back, but the market reaction was entirely different.

title: From Bezos to Dr. Phil, the Enquirer Turns to Bare Knuckle Tactics
summary: Tabloid has tried to use damaging claims as leverage in disputes with celebrities like Richard Simmons and Joe Scarborough. Amazon.com Inc. founder Jeff Bezos' claim that the National Enquirer tried to blackmail him after obtaining embarrassing photos of the tycoon shocked some observers, but it might ring familiar to other celebrities who have tangled with the supermarket tabloid, including fitness guru Richard Simmons and talk-show host Dr. Phil.

title: Today's Logistics Report: XPO's Acquisition Shift; Amazon Drops Big Apple; Aviation's Jumbo Reversal
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: In Weedkiller Case, the Science Will Go on Trial First
summary: Judge's novel approach is latest attempt to resolve long-running legal debate over cases that hinge on complex scientific questions.

title: The Science of Better Meetings
summary: You can't abolish office gatherings, but you can make them shorter, smaller and smarter with the help of recent research. "I wish I could go to more meetings," said no one, ever. Meetings consume and waste a massive, rising amount of individual and organizational time. In a survey last year by Salary.com, "too many meetings" was the top time-waster at the office, cited by 47% of 3,164 workers. The scheduling platform Doodle estimates that 700 million hours will be lost in U.S. workplaces this year to unnecessary or wasteful meetings.

title: Nissan Enlisted Japanese Government to Fend Off Renault Merger
summary: Intervention reveals the tensions that simmered before Nissan executives began investigating former Chairman Carlos Ghosn. Months before the arrest of auto titan Carlos Ghosn, the Japanese government intervened in talks about whether to merge Nissan Motor Co. and Renault SA, according to a person familiar with the deliberations.

title: The Hidden Valley in the Italian Alps Where Winemakers Are Working Against Nature
summary: As climate change reshapes winemaking around the globe, this region is turning out wines of distinction in extreme conditions. This is a place where you find man working against nature," says Danilo Drocco, director of Nino Negri, a 122-year-old winery in the Alpine valley of Valtellina, Italy. "It's a fight. It's not normal to work and make wine here." He downshifts as his car strains to climb the narrow, winding, white-knuckle roads toward Inferno, a subzone infamous for its near-vertical incline, rocky soil and blistering heat in summer. There is a phrase for this kind of winemaking in Italy: viticoltura eroica, or "heroic viticulture," founded in the belief that grapes grown in the most extreme places, exposed to the harshest conditions and highest elevations, disclose a special intensity and sublime elegance.

title: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Rises
summary: Survey finds long-term inflation expectations fell early in February. Consumers' outlook for the U.S. economy rose in early February as American households absorbed the end of the government shutdown and the Federal Reserve's decision to pause its rate increases.

title: Vladimir Putin's Bold Push Into the Middle East
summary: Free of Soviet-era baggage, Russia is busy cultivating ties across the region, including key U.S. allies Israel and Saudi Arabia. Last December, the day after President Donald Trump abruptly announced that the U.S. was pulling out of Syria, Vladimir Putin sounded magnanimous about the American decision. When asked at his annual year-end press conference about Mr. Trump's assessment that Islamic State had been defeated in Syria, the Russian strongman replied, "Overall, I agree with the president of the United States." Mr. Putin added, "Is the presence of American troops required there? I do not think it is."

title: Tom Fatjo Discovered Gold Mine in Garbage
summary: Houston entrepreneur founded Browning-Ferris Industries before vowing to create 'the IBM of Fitness'. Tom Fatjo was working as an accountant in 1966 when he stumbled on an opportunity that struck him as more promising: garbage collection.

title: Best-Selling Books, Week Ended Feb. 9
summary: With data from NPD BookScan. NPD BookScan gathers point-of-sale book data from more than 16,000 locations across the U.S., representing about 85% of the nation's book sales. Print-book data providers include all major booksellers, web retailers and food stores. E-book data providers include all major e-book retailers. Free e-books and those selling for less than 99 cents are excluded from the ebook lists. The fiction and nonfiction combined lists include aggregated sales for all book formats (except audio books, bundles, boxed sets and foreign language editions) and feature a combination of adult, young adult and juvenile titles. The hardcover fiction and nonfiction lists also encompass a mix of adult, young adult and juvenile titles while the business list features only adult hardcover titles. Refer questions to Teresa.Vozzo@wsj.com.

title: Rival Logistics Operators Bid for Swiss Freight Major
summary: Danish freight forwarder DSV sweetens its offer after Panalpina enters talks on 'strategic opportunities' with rival Agility Group. Global logistics operators in Denmark and Kuwait are vying for control of Swiss freight major Panalpina Welttransport Holding AG, potentially setting off a bidding war over consolidation in the world-wide market for industrial transport trade.

title: WSJ. Magazine Editor's Letter: Ripeness Is All
summary: Editor in Chief Kristina O'Neill introduces the March 2019 issue of WSJ. Magazine. As we spring forward into the new year, our March Women's Fashion issue is full of stories of fresh starts and reinvention. For chef Massimo Bottura, whose Osteria Francescana in Modena, Italy, regained the No. 1 spot on the World's 50 Best Restaurants list last year, it takes the form of a project outside the city limits: a 12-room country inn for hosting travelers, parties and VIP dinners. The estate was in ruins when Bottura and his wife, Lara Gilmore, acquired it. The couple has since renovated the place and infused it with new life-with jazz, contemporary art and world-class cooking-creating an intimate destination in the heart of Emilia-Romagna.

title: WSJ. Magazine Contributors: March 2019
summary: Writer Hari Kunzru contributed to this issue of the magazine. For thisfashion portfolio, model Imaan Hammam, photographer Ethan James Green and stylist Anastasia Barbieri headed out to a near-abandoned hacienda in Mexico's Yucatán. "The fashion was inspired by the beauty of the queens and goddesses of ancient Egypt," says Barbieri, who sought to capture a style she described as "very refined but also quite contemporary." Posing against crumbling walls and a pink salt lake, Hammam seemed at once royal and relatable. "I was hypnotized by Imaan's beauty and elegance, the way she moved and gave life and beautiful silhouettes to the dresses," says Barbieri. For Hammam, the shoot was all about losing herself in the present. "When you're in the moment on set, it's all of this chaos going around," she says. "There's music, laughing, dancing, lighting, people shouting, lots of people putting clothes on you. You're doing these poses but not entirely sure everything is working. You have to trust the process and the team."

title: 'Spearhead' Review: Beyond the Front Lines
summary: In World War II, every American tank became a rolling town on tracks.. Small-unit combat has held a special place in literature since the time of Herodotus. From Spartans at Thermopylae to the First Marines at Fallujah, "band of brothers" tales provide a voyeuristic glimpse into war's charnel house and a testament to the sublime and profane within the embattled men on the spear's tip.

title: Real-Estate Deals Targeted Again in Renewed Russia Sanctions Bill
summary: U.S. has been tracking all-cash deals in certain cities for years, but the legislation would apply the effort nation-wide. A bipartisan group of U.S. senators reintroduced sanctions legislation this week targeting Russia that also includes a provision tackling money laundering in all-cash purchases of real estate.

title: 'Lincoln's Confidant' Review: The Friend Who Listened
summary: Journalist Noah Brooks didn't think much of Lincoln when they met in 1856. But the two men became friends when Brooks went to Washington six years later, and his conversations with Lincoln are essential to how we understand the era.. The first time the journalist Noah Brooks saw Abraham Lincoln, in 1856, he was underwhelmed. The former one-term congressman had come to address a Republican club in Dixon, Ill., where Brooks worked and lived. As Brooks later recalled: "Almost everyone was disappointed at the personal appearance of Lincoln." Brooks described him as "sallow in complexion . . . with long arms hanging awkwardly . . . his small head covered with short dark hair brushed carelessly back." It all changed when Lincoln spoke: "There was an irresistible force of logic, a clinching power of argument, and a manly disregard of everything like sophistry or claptrap, which could not fail to arrest the attention and favorably impress the most prejudiced mind."

title: 'Diderot' Review: Wherever His Mind Led Him
summary: Diderot was a voracious reader, an intrepid thinker, a warmhearted friend, a tireless writer, a doting father and an ardent conversationalist.. The name Denis Diderot today rings no bells with the vast majority of the American public, yet the French regard him as one of the brightest luminaries of their civilization. They read him, argue about him, write voluminously about his intellectual and artistic contribution, and are even required, at a fairly tender age, to answer examination questions about his work.

title: Five Best: Laura Marcus on Memoirs of Childhood
summary: The author, most recently, of 'Autobiography: A Very Short Introduction' selects writers' accounts of their early lives.. By Edmund Gosse (1907)

title: 'Becoming Lincoln' Review: The Center That Held
summary: How did Lincoln respond to deep social division? As president he avoided insults or self-promotion. While pushing for justice, he tried to position himself as a pragmatist.. Another account of Abraham Lincoln? Aren't there enough of them? Actually, no. Among the 16,000-plus books on Lincoln, there have been many superb ones, some of them long (e.g., the 10-volume 1890 opus by John Nicolay and John Hay); others short, such as James McPherson's lean biography of 2009; and others midsize, like David Herbert Donald's single-volume classic, titled simply "Lincoln" (1995). There is always room for another, of course. But any new work faces the question: What is being added to the Lincoln literature?

title: Fiction: The Flavor of the American Century
summary: A fizzy, thrilling history of the rise and fall of an imagined soda-pop empire.. Are you old enoughto remember PanCola? For much of the 20th century Panola Cola rivaled Coke and Pepsi as America's soft drink of choice, its slogan ("The Sweetest Thing") a household phrase and its secret ingredient the source of high-profile speculation, until chronic mismanagement drove the company into bankruptcy, the most dramatic casualty of the long-running Cola Wars.

title: 'Goodbye to Tenth Street' Review: A Final Sweeping
summary: A lively novel of the Abstract Expressionist art scene that is everything you'd expect from critic Irving Sandler, who seemingly befriended every painter, writer and dealer in 1950s New York.. Irving Sandler's novel "Goodbye to Tenth Street" is set in a faraway world where tavern-goers sit around all night without buying anything, Jackson Pollock or Andy Warhol is always somewhere at the party, and up-and-comers say things like, "There's a philosophy I find meaningful called Existentialism"-in short, lower Manhattan in the 1950s and '60s.

title: 'Landfall' Review: How It Really Never Happened
summary: Thomas Mallon's superbly written novel about the George W. Bush administration takes its characters more seriously than the media of the time took their real-life counterparts.. Once upon a time,the ethics of treating historical events through fictional narratives was a hotly disputed thing. When Walter Scott invented the historical novel in the early 19th century, the idea of making things up about documented events shocked readers of a conservative frame of mind.

title: Children's Books: Tales Well Worth Repeating
summary: A reissued classic and 10 old yarns cleverly 'respun.'. A young girl named Sophie has a secret possession, "a fragment of glass the size of an almond" that inveigles her into narcissism with a "thin gnat's voice." The glass is enchanted, of course, as are lots of things in the pages of "Straw Into Gold" (McElderry, 293 pages, $17.99), a collection of 10 classic fairy tales "re-spun" by the English writer Hilary McKay.

title: The Structure of Abstraction
summary: Born in Germany, Hans Hofmann found inspiration in American landscapes. Hans Hofmann disliked artistic labels and once told his New York art dealer, "If I ever find a style I'll stop painting." His seemingly freewheeling approach to making art sometimes confused critics, who tended to underestimate him. But "Hans Hofmann: The Nature of Abstraction," which will be on view from Feb. 27 to July 21 at the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive, in Berkeley, Calif., reveals an artist whose explorations of color and form were a lot more systematic than he is usually given credit for.

title: Mysteries: Still Prepared to Kill
summary: In Kate Quinn's thriller a woman who killed Jewish refugees during World War II makes a new life in Boston-but is still prepared to kill.. The title character in Kate Quinn's "The Huntress" (Morrow, 530 pages, $16.99), a historical thriller set from the late 1930s to the early '50s, is an Austrian woman known by a series of names. As the mistress of an SS officer, she is Lorelei Vogt; as a refugee from postwar Europe, Anneliese Weber; as the chic wife of a widowed Boston antiques dealer, Anna McBride. She earned her Huntress moniker in the waning days of World War II, as an enthusiastic killer of escaped camp prisoners and Jewish refugees (including half a dozen children).

title: 'A German Officer in Occupied Paris' Review: A Very Refined Occupation
summary: As France's Jews were deported and horrors unfolded in the East, Ernst Jünger spent his days in Paris collecting rare books, cultivating mistresses, filling his diaries with aphorisms and mingling in the moral soup with Pablo Picasso, Jean Cocteau and others.. No German writer was better placed for observing the German occupation of Paris than Ernst Jünger. A hero of World War I, wounded 14 times and awarded the Iron Cross, First Class, Jünger was internationally famous for his trench memoir "Storm of Steel" (1920). Between the wars, he studied insects, read Nietzsche and fought in the Weimar streets with the anti-leftist Freikorps militia. Beginning in 1941, Jünger worked in military intelligence from an office in the luxurious Hôtel Majestic, gathering information for the army generals on Resistance activities as well as on the Nazi party apparatus, which the Wehrmacht often found itself at odds with. But he also spent his days in Paris collecting rare books, cultivating mistresses, coining aphorisms to add to his diaries and mingling in the moral soup with artists and writers including Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque, as well as the collaborators Jean Cocteau, Louis Ferdinand Céline and Henry de Montherlant. "Some people had dirty hands," Cocteau said after the war, "some had clean hands, but Jünger had no hands." Jünger's war diaries, translated here with damning clarity by Thomas and Abby Hansen, are a fascinating, refined and disturbing record of the moral disasters of Nazism and collaboration.

title: Factory Output Contracts Unexpectedly in January
summary: Industrial production falls 0.6%, primarily driven by a large drop in vehicle production. WASHINGTON-U.S. industrial output fell sharply in January because of a large drop in vehicle production, adding fuel to rising worries about the current economic expansion.

title: Stocks to Watch: Nvidia, CBS, Deere, PepsiCo, Newell, FedEx
summary: Resume Subscription. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Download the WSJ Tax Guide E-Book
Exclusive: Step Inside YSL's New Parisian Headquarters
summary: The current occupants of this former abbey have taken a vow of eternal chic. Anthony Vaccarello has nearly finished giving a tour of the just-opened 140,000-square-foot headquarters of fashion house Yves Saint Laurent in a tony corner of Paris's seventh arrondissement when, heading toward the exit, he says he's saved his favorite part for last. After looping across the vast courtyard of the former 18th-century abbey, through the showrooms, we pass through the front gate at the rue de Bellechasse. There, on the driveway at the edge of the sidewalk, the cobblestones under our feet rumble as we slowly start to descend: It turns out to be a platform elevator that takes us down, Bond-villain style, to a small parking lot. Painted black lacquer with gleaming white markers, it's more appropriate for an upscale bondage club than a place to stash the company's off-duty town cars.

title: Regulators Block Fewer M&A Deals
summary: Partners are completing deals because they are showing a willingness to compromise to ease concerns over issues such as gaining too much pricing power in certain markets. When the proposed train merger between Siemens AG and Alstom SA was blocked by the European Union last week, several observers seized on it as fresh evidence of a regulatory clampdown on deal making.

title: The Latest Chapter in Europe's Electoral Challenges: Spain
summary: After three years of shaky, minority governments, Spaniards will vote in an election that could produce a stalemate. A new, hard-right party could play kingmaker.. Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez called snap general elections for late April, bringing the curtain down early on a short-lived government and pitching Spain into a vote that is likely to produce a fragmented legislature and could showcase the rising strength of a new, hard-right party.

title: Big Dividends Close Door on Battered Bank's Desperate Decade
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland has finally recovered from the financial crisis, but now looks worth a gamble on a benign Brexit. Royal Bank of Scotland has escaped its desperate decade-the years in which the world's largest bank by assets on the eve of the 2008 crisis was battered, bailed out and, for a long time, badly managed.

title: Buy Low on LeBron James and the Lakers
summary: The Lakers are in jeopardy of missing the NBA playoffs. Here's why they're better than you think. (Hint: They still have a guy who's pretty good at basketball.). This has not been the happiest season for the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: New Tariffs Threaten to Boost Prices of Imported Cars, Parts
summary: Commerce Report to Trump Could Recommend 20% Levies. American car buyers are facing sticker shock as President Trump weighs new tariffs on imported vehicles and auto parts.

title: What You Need to Know About the New Tax Law (Now That You're Doing Your Taxes)
summary: The Wall Street Journal's 2019 Tax Guide will help you sort through the confusion of doing your taxes for the first time under the new law. It's time for Americans to meet the new tax law.

title: Venezuela Opposition's Man in D.C. Seeks to Rally U.S. Support
summary: Guaidó's envoy to Washington is charged with managing the parallel government's relationship with its most crucial ally. DORAL, Fla.-Carlos Vecchio received a rapturous response as he took the stage on a recent afternoon at a church filled with Venezuelan exiles in this Miami suburb.

title: New Tax Rates and Brackets
summary: Tax overhaul changed rates and income brackets, but whether people owe more or less will often depend on other provisions. The tax overhaul altered rates and brackets, but not as much as some proposed. Instead, the major changes affecting Americans often stem from other provisions, such as the expanded standard deduction or child tax credit.

title: Standard-Deduction Expansion and Personal Exemption
summary: The expansion of the standard deduction and repeal of the personal exemption affect millions of Americans. For many people, the tax overhaul's most sweeping changes are the near-doubling of the standard deduction and repeal of the personal exemption.

title: Child and Dependent Tax Credit
summary: The child credit doubled and became available to more families, a move that more than offset the repeal of the personal exemption in many cases. The tax overhaul doubled the maximum child tax credit to $2,000 from $1,000 for each child in a family under age 17 at year-end.

title: Withholding and Estimated Tax Payments
summary: Employees should refigure paycheck withholding or risk unwelcome surprises. More than 90% of employees saw bigger paychecks in 2018, after the Treasury Department made automatic adjustments to paycheck withholding based on the overhaul's changes. The withholding changes also applied to pension payments.

title: Taxes on Investment Income
summary: The overhaul made few changes to investment-income taxes, preserving the favorable rates for capital gains and dividends.

title: The Alternative Minimum Tax
summary: After vowing to kill it, Republicans kept this unpopular levy, but they revised it to affect far fewer people.

title: Home-Seller's Exemption
summary: Nothing changed, despite an initial effort by House Republicans to reduce the benefit. Despite proposed changes, the tax overhaul retained the existing benefit for home sellers.

title: The 'Kiddie Tax'
summary: The overhaul greatly simplified a special levy on a child's 'unearned' income, but the shift in rates is unfavorable for some.

title: Estate and Gift Taxes
summary: Lawmakers didn't repeal the estate tax, but they doubled the exemption, reducing the number of liable estates. The overhaul doubled the estate- and gift-tax exemption, which is a combined amount that applies to an individual's gifts made during life or assets left at death.

title: State and Local Tax Deduction
summary: The overhaul capped the deduction for state and local taxes at $10,000 per return. In a landmark change, the tax overhaul put a cap on deductions for state and local taxes, known as SALT. Previously these deductions were unlimited for individuals, although many people who owed the alternative minimum tax lost the benefit of some or all of their SALT write-offs.

title: Mortgage-Interest Deduction
summary: The near-doubling of the standard deduction and caps on eligible mortgages mean fewer will take popular write-off.

title: Charitable-Donation Tax Deduction
summary: The overhaul didn't make major changes to these deductions, but the near-doubling of the standard deduction means far fewer filers will choose to itemize. The number of tax returns claiming deductions for charitable contributions is expected drop by more than 50% as a result of the overhaul. For 2018, about 15 million filers will take this write-off, compared with about 36 million for 2017, according to the Tax Policy Center.

title: Medical-Expenses Deduction
summary: After considering ending it, lawmakers retained this write-off and made it slightly more generous. An attempt by the House to end the deduction for medical expenses provoked an intense reaction because it would have affected people in nursing homes and those with expensive chronic illnesses.

title: Alimony
summary: Future payments are expected to shrink as a result of the tax overhaul. The overhaul made a major change to the tax status of alimony payments. Payers won't be able to deduct alimony on their tax returns for divorce and separation agreements signed after 2018.

title: Other Tax Deductions
summary: Many write-offs have been curtailed, including those for unreimbursed employee travel expenses.

title: Retirement Savings
summary: Tax law changes time frame of 401(k) loan repayments and ends savers' ability to 'undo' Roth IRA conversions. Lawmakers backed off a controversial proposal to lower the amount Americans can contribute before taxes to 401(k) and similar retirement-savings plans. But they did make other changes affecting savers who have these plans.

title: Retiree Tax Issues
summary: The overhaul didn't change the taxation of Social Security benefits or retirement-plan distributions, but the big increase in the standard deduction will benefit many retirees. A key change of the overhaul will be positive for many retirees: the near-doubling of the standard deduction. For individuals it is $12,000 for 2018 and $12,200 for 2019, while for married couples filing jointly it is $24,000 for 2018 and $24,400 for 2019.

title: 529 Education Savings Accounts
summary: These plans can now be used to pay up to $10,000 of K-12 private-school tuition, but clarifications are needed in some states. The tax overhaul made so-called 529 accounts more flexible-but there is also a downside.

title: Other Education Benefits
summary: The House had planned a major shake-up-but in the end, Congress passed very few changes. Many changes related to education seemed to be on the horizon as the tax overhaul took shape. In the end, Congress didn't enact several that were approved by the House of Representatives.

title: Deduction for Pass-Through Income
summary: Owners of pass-through businesses get a break-but figuring out who is eligible could be challenging. The overhaul created a new deduction of 20% for many pass-through business owners, making their top tax rate 29.6% instead of the 37% rate that applies to top earners' wages and other income. Lawmakers made the change as a way to assist firms that won't benefit from the cut in the top corporate rate to 21% from 35%.

title: The Tax Cut's Economic Impact
summary: Economists expected a boost in the first two years after the law was passed, but longer-term effects remain less clear. President Trump and Republicans bet that the 2017 tax overhaul would invigorate the U.S. economy after a long but slow expansion, putting controversial economic theories about growth to a crucial test.

title: WSJ Tax Guide 2019: What Investors Need to Know
summary: Companies are beginning to understand how the tax rules could reshape their operations. A little more than a year on, companies are only just gearing up to put the 2017 tax overhaul to work.

title: The Individual Mandate
summary: The Obamacare requirement to have health insurance or pay a penalty is gone for 2019. Republicans used the tax overhaul to achieve a health-policy aim: eliminating the individual mandate to have health insurance, a centerpiece of the 2010 Affordable Care Act.

title: Interest Payments on Business Debt
summary: The overhaul put a cap on the amount of interest cost that most companies can deduct. Heavily indebted companies are facing new limits on their ability to deduct interest payments from their tax returns, a change that makes business debt less attractive.

title: Depreciation for Business Equipment
summary: Tax law allows companies to immediately write off 100% of equipment purchases, an extraordinary-albeit temporary-perk. Businesses buying equipment are getting an extraordinary new benefit from the new tax law: the ability to deduct the entire cost of their equipment purchases in the first year.

title: The Political Implications of the Tax Overhaul
summary: The tax law was the GOP's biggest achievement, but it remained unpopular as Republicans tried to use it to win elections. Republicans hoped their 2017 tax law would be a political winner, putting money into voters' pockets and delivering victories into the GOP column. That didn't happen.

title: The Tech Industry
summary: Tech companies paid low effective tax rates under the old system by booking profits in low-tax foreign jurisdictions. The tax overhaul seeks to curtail the practice.. The drop in the corporate tax rate to 21% from 35% boosted the profits of most companies, but those gains were partially offset by one-time mandatory levies on the huge overseas cash stockpiles they accumulated under the old system.

title: The Banking Industry
summary: For banks, after some initial pain, the tax overhaul has been a multibillion-dollar windfall. Banks have been among the biggest beneficiaries of the tax overhaul, reaping billions of dollars in savings after the corporate tax rate was cut to 21% from 35%.

title: The Housing Market
summary: By shrinking the tax benefits of homeownership, the tax law is starting to have a big impact on the housing market. The tax-code overhaul that partially wiped out decades-old perks designed to encourage homeownership is slowly beginning to reshape the housing market and give an extra push to those considering fleeing high-tax states.

title: The Drug Industry
summary: The tax overhaul has given pharmaceutical companies that generate hefty sales outside the U.S. the chance to bring cash home at a preferential rate.. Multinational drug companies were big beneficiaries from the tax overhaul because they generate a good chunk of their sales outside the U.S. and had been keeping billions of dollars overseas to avoid having to pay U.S. taxes on the sums. They now have an opportunity to repatriate that money at a preferential rate.

title: The Telecom Industry
summary: Telecom carriers are benefiting from the lower tax rate and a 100% write-off on capital investments as they gear up for 5G networks. Because most telecommunications carriers' revenue comes from domestic operations, the reduced corporate tax rate is saving many of them billions of dollars each year. Another provision that allows companies to immediately write off the full value of their capital investments through 2022 also offers them big near-term savings.

title: The Retail Industry
summary: The tax cut could help an industry spending heavily to fight Amazon and adapt to shifting consumer habits. As an industry that pays one of the highest average corporate-tax rates, retailers have been one of the largest beneficiaries of the new tax legislation, which lowered the rate to 21%.

title: BP: Renewables and Natural Gas to Dominate Energy Growth
summary: The energy giant's projections show oil demand peaking in less than two decades. LONDON-The vast majority of global energy supply growth is expected to come from renewables and natural gas over the next two decades, but steep investment in oil exploration and production will be needed to meet crude demand in 2040, BP PLC said Thursday.

title: Chinese, U.S. Trade Negotiators Inch Toward a Broad Agreement
summary: Top officials from both sides will hold further talks next week in Washington. BEIJING-China and the U.S. inched toward a broad agreement aimed at defusing their market-rattling trade tensions, with top negotiators agreeing to further talks next week in Washington after a weeklong session here.

title: A Look at African-American History, Through the Numbers
summary: In recognition of Black History Month, here are a few facts and figures about the African-American experience in the U.S.. Four hundred years ago, the first Africans arrived in what is now the U.S.

title: New Consumer CEOs Are Getting Tougher, Shorter Jobs
summary: Incoming bosses at Colgate-Palmolive, PepsiCo and Unilever must solve knottier problems than their predecessors-and probably in less time. Running a multibillion-dollar consumer company is a more bruising job than it used to be. The new bosses may struggle to last as long as the retiring ones.

title: China's Didi to Lay Off 2,000 Workers
summary: Former fast grower has been hit by economic slowdown, closer scrutiny since two murders last year. BEIJING-Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing Technology Co. plans to lay off about 2,000 employees, or 15% of its workforce, according to people familiar with the situation, as the once fast-growing company grapples with China's economic slowdown.

title: ICE Wants to Bring First 'Speed Bump' to Futures Markets
summary: Plan to introduce brief delay on some gold and silver futures trades is on pause pending CFTC review. A proposal to blunt the advantages of ultrafast traders in one corner of the futures market is threatening to shake up the high-frequency trading world.

title: Hulu Ad Campaign Spells Out That Its Influencers Get Paid
summary: Streaming service begins new push for its live TV service. Streaming service Hulu is adding an element of "authenticity" to its marketing with a campaign where endorsers emphasize that they are getting paid for their services.

title: Fake News Rattles Nigerian Election Campaign
summary: As rumors proliferate, government calls misinformation a threat to credible vote. A recycled image of a baby with machete wounds being peddled as part of a current massacre. A fake endorsement from the U.S. ambassador. Reports that the president has been replaced with a Sudanese body double.

title: Purchases With Plastic Get Costlier for Merchants-and Consumers
summary: Visa and Mastercard plan to raise fees on credit and debit cards, putting new strain on retail. Credit-card companies are increasing a range of fees that U.S. merchants will pay to process transactions, a move likely to inflame already fractious relations between many businesses and card networks.

title: 'Fortnite' Effect: The Game Never Ends
summary: Videogame makers targeting the success of the battle-royale blockbuster need to get millions of players in the door-and keep them paying. Videogames are big business. To get a sense of how big, consider that one giving itself away free has outearned the box-office haul of any Star Wars movie.

title: Myanmar Court Sentences Two Men to Death for Killing of Suu Kyi Aide
summary: Ko Ni was a vocal advocate for a diminished military role in the country. Two years after an adviser to Myanmar's civilian leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, was assassinated outside the country's main international airport, a court handed down death sentences for two men, including the gunman who fired the fatal bullet at close range in front of the victim's grandchild.

title: How to Depress Chinese Consumers Without Really Trying
summary: Hint: By stealing yields on bank deposits. Imagine the following: The labor market is suffering. You're paying off an expensive mortgage while losing money on your bank account. Would you want to fork out for a pricey iPhone?

title: Drone Scare Grounds Flights at Dubai Airport
summary: Dubai airport becomes the latest in a series of global hubs to cancel flights because of nearby drone activity. DUBAI-Dubai International Airport, the world's busiest international hub, briefly suspended flights Friday because of the suspected presence of a drone, the latest in a string of global airports to have to ground flights because of illicit unmanned aircraft operations.

title: China's Muted Inflation Likely to Spur Policy Easing
summary: Weak economic readings could encourage People's Bank of China to stimulate economic growth. BEIJING-Inflation moderated across the board in China last month in another sign of lethargic domestic demand-one that economists said gives the central bank more room to stimulate economic growth.

title: Philippine Towns Blocked From Joining Muslim Self-Rule Region
summary: Province votes to overrule decisions by six towns to become part of new autonomous region. Six southern Philippine towns that voted to join a new self-governing Muslim region have had their decision effectively vetoed-a first challenge to a peace deal supporters hope will stem Islamic extremism.

title: 'I Had No Idea I Was Having a Heart Attack': For Women, the Signals Often Aren't Clear
summary: A retired cardiac-care nurse didn't recognize her own symptoms. Neither did the first responders. It's a problem that can have fatal consequences.. On a sunny day in Bellevue, Wash., in June 2011, I had just completed a workout class when I experienced a bizarre sensation of intense, full-body muscle fatigue. I broke into a bone-chilling sweat. My upper left arm throbbed, a deep ache next to the bone. I was heaving for air at a rapid clip. I grew nauseated. A fist was pressing through my chest to my spine. I was 56 years old, an exercise enthusiast, a nonsmoker and a retired cardiac-care nurse. And yet I had no idea that I was having a heart attack.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Photos: Parkland Shooting, One Year Later
summary: Local residents commemorate the Feb. 14, 2018, shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Trump to Declare Emergency After He Signs Spending Bill
summary: Democrats are expected to challenge any efforts to move money around without congressional approval. WASHINGTON-President Trump plans to sign a spending bill that keeps the government open and will then declare a national emergency to seek more border-wall funding, the White House said, ending the suspense over a possible second shutdown but kicking off a new fight.

title: Amazon Cancels HQ2 Plans in New York City
summary: Company will move ahead with plans in Virginia and Nashville and will hire at other tech hubs. Amazon.com Inc. abandoned its $2.5 billion plan to build a New York City headquarters, undoing one of the country's biggest economic-development deals because it said it was troubled by growing political opposition to subsidies to one of the world's richest companies.

title: Nvidia's Revenue Sinks 24%, but Wall Street Feared Worse
summary: Falling demand for chips used in cryptocurrency mining and gaming weighs on the company's results. Nvidia Corp. reported a 24% drop in quarterly revenue Thursday and signaled work ahead to shake off a funk in cryptocurrency mining and revive demand for its chips used by videogamers and data centers.

title: Amazon May Still See Benefits From Failed New York Courting Process
summary: Executives landed a blueprint for expansion across some of the largest U.S. cities, analysts say. Amazon.com Inc.'s plans for a New York City headquarters may not have panned out, but its search for a second campus may have provided the e-commerce company with invaluable information at a cost that will barely register on its giant balance sheet.

title: Earnings Season to Offer Next Test for Retail Stocks
summary: S&P 500 Retailing index slumps on disappointing retail-sales data. Retail stocks stumbled Thursday after an important measure of consumer spending slumped over the holiday season, raising the stakes for the industry's coming earnings season.

title: N.J. Governor Backs Bill Expanding Statute of Limitations for Sex-Abuse Victims
summary: The measure would also allow victims to sue any liable institution. New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy on Thursday threw his support behind proposed legislation that would expand the statute of limitations in civil cases for sexual-assault victims, a measure long opposed by the state's Roman Catholic Church.

title: China Seeks to Woo U.S. With Promise of Big Chip Purchases
summary: Trade talks remain deadlocked as Beijing refuses to eliminate coerced technology transfers or government subsidies to Chinese companies. BEIJING-China is counting on promises of big purchases of U.S. semiconductors and other goods to ease trade tensions and persuade President Trump to extend a tariff truce and later resolve the market-rattling dispute directly with Chinese leader Xi Jinping.

title: Ares Rides Credit Fundraising Wave to $36.1 Billion Annual Record
summary: The Los Angeles asset manager raised $36.1 billion last year, a record for the firm and more than double the amount it collected in 2017. Ares Management Corp. is banking on another robust year of fundraising in 2019, as the asset manager continues to expand beyond its flagship funds.

title: Guggenheim's Asset-Management Unit Won't Receive Penalty After SEC Investigation
summary: SEC had probed transactions tied to the firm, its chief executive and a Miami financial company run by former Guggenheim managers. Guggenheim Partners LLC said U.S. securities regulators won't take action against the firm following an investigation into its asset-management business.

title: Brazil Says New Government Ready to Help Venezuela, Approve Pension Reform
summary: Vice president details logistical challenges of sending food and medicine while Maduro clings to power and bars shipments from abroad. BRASILIA-Brazil's new government, already fighting allegations of misconduct, is ready to help neighboring Venezuela and approve a controversial pension reform, Vice President Hamilton Mourão said Thursday.

title: Ex-FBI Official McCabe Says He Approved Trump Probe After Comey Firing
summary: Former deputy director tells of worry the case would be buried if he didn't get it under way. WASHINGTON-Former Deputy FBI Director Andrew McCabe approved investigations into President Trump's potential ties to Russia almost immediately after the president fired his former boss in May 2017, Mr. McCabe said in his first public interview since that tumultuous month.

title: Venezuela's Maduro Government Forms U.N. Coalition Against Foreign Interference
summary: Russia, Iran, Syria, North Korea are among members of group. United Nations-Venezuela said Thursday it was joining forces with other U.N. countries to form a coalition that defends the sovereignty of nations against foreign interference.

title: Some Cheered, Others 'Sickened' Over Amazon News in Long Island City, New York
summary: Residents and community leaders voice range of opinions about tech giant's withdrawal from expansion plan. Amazon's decision to abandon plans to build a new campus in Long Island City, Queens, has drawn cheers from several politicians, community organizers and other locals opposed to the expansion. But it has also left some business owners and neighborhood leaders questioning why and how the deal unraveled and what will become of the area without the e-commerce giant.

title: CBS Gets Ready to Press for New NFL Deal
summary: Media company expects a surge in subscribers to its streaming operations; results swing to profit. CBS Corp.'s current contract with the National Football League runs through the 2022 season, but executives at the media company are already making their case to the league for a new deal.

title: Ex-Coke Scientist Accused of Stealing Trade Secrets for China
summary: Alleged theft by naturalized U.S. citizen involved chemical coatings for beverage containers, prosecutors say. A Chinese-born scientist was arrested on charges of trying to steal trade secrets from companies doing research with Coca-Cola Co. , with the intent to set up a competing venture in China and win a reward from a Chinese government-backed program, authorities said.

title: Republicans Need to Save Capitalism
summary: Democrats have gone left, so they're not going to do it. The GOP needs a renewed seriousness.. Let's think about the broader, less immediate meaning of our political era.

title: Readers React to Amazon's New York Reversal
summary: Journal readers reacted in droves, with many slamming politicians and others saying it was the right move. Amazon.com said it is abandoning plans to build a new headquarters in New York City after the company faced stiff resistance from some local politicians who objected to giving one of the world's most valuable companies billions of dollars in tax incentives.

title: A Lesson in Anti-Semitism
summary: Look across the pond to see where the Democrats could end up.. Bipartisan support for Israel has long been a feature of American politics. But as the Democratic Party moves further left, it is increasingly home to vociferous anti-Israel voices. An anti-Semitism crisis in the United Kingdom's Labour Party shows what happens when a political party doesn't rebut such views.

title: Trump's Political Emergency
summary: His border order will divide Republicans and may be stopped in court.. The White House said Thursday that President Trump will sign a border-security funding bill but also declare a national emergency to spend even more to build his wall at the Rio Grande. The emergency declaration will please his most ardent supporters, but Mr. Trump is setting an unfortunate precedent-and judges could tie up his wall in court for years.

title: Amazon's HQ2 Reversal Highlights Risks of Public Perception in Site Selection
summary: Backlash may indicate that the company miscalculated potential risks in the process, consultants say. Amazon.com Inc.'s decision to cancel plans for a new headquarters in New York highlights, on a grand scale, one of the biggest risks companies face when planning ambitious expansions: securing public support.

title: 'Aristotle's Way' Review: Philosophize and Flourish
summary: In an age obsessed with subjective happiness, he offers us a challenge, suggesting that we concentrate instead on living virtuously.. There is no shortage of books promising to show "how ancient wisdom can change your life," the generic subtitle of classicist Edith Hall's new book. What distinguishes "Aristotle's Way" from its predecessors is that its eponymous subject really can deliver on the promise.

title: Historian Challenges Lombardi's Pizza Primacy
summary: Chicago researcher points to evidence that pizza was introduced in New York City before Lombardi's. Call it a slice of culinary controversy.
